etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Encyclopaedia Britannica. From German †Physharmonica from ancient Greek ϕῦσα bellows + German †Harmonica (now Harmonika) harmonica

definitions: An early form of harmonium, in which metal springs are set in vibration by a current of air.

notes.text: This form of harmonium was invented by Anton Häckl of Vienna 1820, and was originally designed to be attached to a piano.
